questions.question: Question 1: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus?
questions.explanation: Mucicarmine stain is used in the identification of cryptococcus. Mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci:

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is a false statement regarding Cryptococcus neoformans?

options.b: It most commonly causes meningitis in AIDS patients
options.c: There are 3 serological types based on capsular polysaccharide
options.d: Niger seed agar is used to demonstrate melanin production

questions.explanation:
Pathogenic varieties of cryptococcus including C. neoformans and C. gattii are laccase positive. 
They also have ability to grow at 37° C and these factors are used to differentiate them from 
non-pathogenic cryptococci. Cryptococci have been classified into 5 serotypes (A, B, C, D, and AD) based on their capsular 
polysaccharide: • Three serotypes fall under Cryptococcus neoformans - A(var. grubii), D(var. neoformans), and 
AD(a hybrid of serotypes A and D). Although serotype AD is very similar to serotypes A and D, the 
isolates still comprise a discrete group that can be distinguished. • The serotypes B and C are now considered a different species - Cryptococcus gattii. Niger seed agar is a solid medium used for selective and differential isolation 
of Cryptococcus neoformans from clinical specimens. C. neoformans and C. gattii produces brown 480 
Sold by @itachibot colonies on this medium due to the formation of melanin. Melanin is produced by laccase 
using caffeic acid as the substrate. The following image shows pigmented colonies of C. gattii growing on niger seed agar. Cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, is an opportunistic infection seen in 
individuals with AIDS. Flucytosine and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of this 
condition.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following organisms cannot be grown on any culture media?
questions.explanation:
Rhinosporidium seeberi and Pneumocystis jirovecii are non-cultivable organisms and cannot be 
grown on any culture media. Another example of a non-cultivable fungus is Lacazia loboi. It causes Jorge Lobo's disease which 
is a chronic subcutaneous mycosis. Rhizopus oryzae is a mold which is easily cultivable on SDA. Dimorphic fungi like Histoplasma 
capsulatum and Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis are identified based on their colony morphology on 
SDA. Note: Recently, molecular biological techniques have demonstrated that Rhinosporidium is 
an aquatic protistan parasite. Infections due to Rhinosporidium have been classified under 
infections due to Protozoa under the ICD 11.

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient with HIV presented complaining of cough and progressively worsening breathing 
difficulty. Chest X-ray showed bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The findings of microscopic 
examination of his bronchoalveolar lavage is given below. Which is the most probable 
causative organism? 473 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture and the GMS stained smear showing the black-colored cysts 
resembling crushed ping pong balls are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) caused by 
Pneumocystis jirovecii. 481 
Sold by @itachibot Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive. Chest 
X-ray is either a normal film if the disease is suspected early, or with diffuse bilateral interstitial 
infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS. Treatment of choice is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole) and pentamidine 
isethionate. Cotrimoxazole can also be used for prophylaxis in patients having AIDS. The following X-ray image shows a cyst (arrow) and bilateral lung infiltrates in a patient with PCP:

questions.question:
Question 5: A middle-aged immunocompromised patient presents with complaints of pain during 
swallowing. She describes it as a burning sensation that radiates to her back every time she 
swallows. Oral examination reveals creamy white patches on the oral mucosa. The wet mount 
microscopy of the scraping obtained from the patches is given below. Identify the organism. 474 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of odynophagia, creamy white patches on the oral mucosa and the wet 
mount microscopy showing budding yeasts with pseudohyphae are suggestive of oral candidiasis 
caused by Candida albicans. 482 
Sold by @itachibot It is an opportunistic infection commonly seen in immunocompromised states like AIDS, diabetes 
etc. Treatment includes topical azoles or nystatin.

questions.question: Question 6: The following test is positive for identification of
questions.explanation:
The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans. Unlike other species of candida, yeast cells of Candida albicans will begin to form germ tubes after 
incubation in serum maintained at 37°C for about 90 minutes. This is known as the 
Reynolds-Braude phenomenon. This test is positive for Candia dubliniensis as well.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 35-year-old HIV positive■ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in 
the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the 
likely diagnosis? 475 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis. Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, 
lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative 
agent is usually Candida albicans. It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular 
immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics. It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole. Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It 
is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue. Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the 
flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as 
lacy, white, and raised lesions. Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the 
tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.question: Question 8: Galactomannan in serum is seen in:
questions.explanation:
The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive (deep-seated) mycoses caused by 
Aspergillus species. Galactomannan is a component of the cell wall of Aspergillus. It can be detected in serum or 
bronchoalveolar lavage by ELISA for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis in adults and children. 
This test is especially useful in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients or patients with 
hematologic malignancies. Other diagnostic features of invasive aspergillosis are: • A positive culture from the affected organ 483 
Sold by @itachibot • Aspergillus antigen detection of galactomannan • Narrow, septate hyphae with branching at 45o and conidiophores • Halo sign on CT scan

questions.question:
Question 9: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain. 476 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given slide stained with GMS shows acute-angled (45o) uniform, branching septate hyphae 
which is suggestive of Aspergillus species. Aspergillus species grow rapidly, producing aerial hyphae that bear characteristic conidial 
structures. Long aseptate conidiophores are seen with terminal vesicles on which phialides are 
arranged in basipetal chains. The following image shows the lactophenol cotton blue solution (LPCB) mount of Aspergillus 
fumigatus showing the long conidiophores with terminal vesicles. Option A: Mucor produces nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a 
sporangium. Option B: Penicillium produces septate hyphae with branched, septate and brush-like 
conidiophores. Option D: Rhizopus appears similar to Mucor but it has rhizoids with sporangiophores arising in 
groups directly above the rhizoids.

questions.question:
Question 10: A young lady complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for 
two years. She has a history of allergic rhinitis. On rhinoscopy, multiple ethmoidal polyps 
with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in both the nasal cavities. A tissue 
biopsy is taken and sent for culture, which on microscopic examination shows the following 
appearance. What is the most probable organism implicated here? 477 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture and the microscopic appearance is suggestive of fungal rhinosinusitis. 
The most probable causative organism is Aspergillus fumigatus. It is commonly involved in 
paranasal sinus mycoses (fungal sinusitis). 484 
Sold by @itachibot The disease has been described to have four types: • allergic • non-invasive • invasive • fulminant A possible fifth type called non-invasive destructive type may also exist. Zygomycetes like mucor and rhizopus are the common agents in fulminant type of fungal 
sinusitis. The characteristic microscopic appearance of Aspergillus fumigatus: • The vesicle is conical. • Phialides are arranged in a single row. • Conidia arise from the upper third of the vesicle and are hyaline. Option B: Aspergillus flavus appears as follows: • The vesicle is globular. • Phialides are arranged in one or two rows. • Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline. Option C: Aspergillus niger appear as follows: 485 
Sold by @itachibot • The vesicle is globular shaped. • Phialides are in two rows. • Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black. Option D: Penicillium chrysogenum appear as follows: • Septate hyphae with branched conidiophores bearing chains of spores(brush or broom 
appearance).

questions.question: Question 11: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.explanation:
Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. It can 
also be used against candida species (including glabrata and krusei), scedosporium and fusarium. 486 
Sold by @itachibot The other options can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary 
aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

questions.question: Question 12:  1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except?
questions.explanation:
The  1-3 glucan assay cannot be used to diagnose mucormycosis. This condition is usually 
diagnosed based on clinical features and culture. The test detects the presence of (1-3)--d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall 
polysaccharide found in most fungi. It is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D Glucan by 
using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. 1,3 Beta D Glucan level of 
80 pg/mL is considered a positive result. Fungi that do not contain BDG in their cell walls include • Cryptococcus neoformans • Zygomycetes like rhizopus and mucor • Blastomyces dermatitidis Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis caused by zygomycetes, which do not contain 
(1-3)--d-glucan, and hence, the  1-3 glucan assay cannot be used for its diagnosis.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic 
ketoacidosis ?
questions.explanation:
Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic 
ketoacidosis. Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. 
Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus 
and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

questions.question:
Question 14: 478 
Sold by @itachibot A 68-year-old post-COVID-19 patient presented with a black, foul-smelling nasal discharge 
and blurred vision. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass eroding the septum and hard 
palate was visualised. Lactophenol cotton blue mount from the culture is given below. Which 
of the following statements is false regarding the condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the LPCB mount showing aseptate hyphae branching at 
right-angles is strongly suggestive of mucormycosis. Rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis is the 
most common form of mucormycosis. Pulmonary mucormycosis is the second most common 
form. Mucormycosis is an invasive disease caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, 
and Lichtheimia. The disease is often characterized by hyphae growing in and around the blood 
vessels. It can turn fatal on cerebral involvement and development of speticemia. Risk factors for the infection include: • Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis). 487 
Sold by @itachibot • Elevated levels of free iron. • Defects in phagocytic function. • Organ or hematopoietic stem transplantation. Treatment of choice is Amphotericin-B. Posaconazole can be used as an alternative drug. 488 
Sold by @itachibot General Parasitology
